title: Building a Rapid Learning Tool with Bun and Aider
summary: This workflow demonstrates how to leverage Bun's unified runtime to build a CLI tool that scrapes technical documentation. The extracted data is then fed into Aider, an AI coding assistant, to automatically generate and verify working code examples. This creates a rapid, agentic learning loop that bypasses manual setup and context switching common in the Node.js ecosystem.

steps.reasoning: Sets up the project structure (package.json, tsconfig.json) instantly without needing separate initialization for TypeScript or node modules.
Installs necessary libraries (cheerio, axios, figlet) significantly faster than npm, preparing the environment for the scraping tool.

steps.action: Implement Environment and CLI Argument Parsing
steps.reasoning: Establishes a robust configuration layer to handle dynamic URLs and file paths, essential for a reusable agentic tool.
Retrieves raw documentation content from the target URL to serve as the knowledge base for the AI agent.
Cleans the raw HTML to retain only high-value context (headers and code blocks), reducing token usage and noise for the AI model.
Persists the processed documentation into a 'memory' directory, creating a tangible context file that the AI agent can ingest.
Sets up the AI coding assistant within a Git repository, allowing it to track changes and manage the codebase.
Feeds the specific scraped documentation (e.g., JSON reading guide) into the agent's context window.
Instructs the agent to synthesize the documentation into a functioning code example, automating the 'learning' phase.
Executes the AI-generated code immediately to validate correctness, completing the feedback loop.
Removes old context files (`/drop`) before adding new ones to optimize token usage and prevent context pollution during subsequent tasks.
Demonstrates Bun's all-in-one toolkit by running tests generated by the agent without needing external test runners like Jest.

key_takeaways: Bun reduces developer friction by unifying the runtime, package manager, and test runner into a single cohesive tool.
Agentic workflows can accelerate learning by automating the translation of documentation into working code examples.
Preprocessing data (scraping and filtering HTML) is critical for effective AI context injection, ensuring the model focuses on relevant code and logic.
The combination of fast runtimes (Bun) and AI agents (Aider) creates a high-velocity feedback loop for prototyping and problem-solving.
